paragraphs.text: Mario Cuomo and the folly of progressivism.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: How precious in the sight of progressives was one of their saints, Mario Cuomo, the three-term governor of New York who died last week at age 82
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He was a model of progressivism and a gifted rhetorician
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In most media accounts, references were made to two speeches Cuomo delivered in 1984, one at the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco where Walter Mondale was nominated for president, and the other at the University of Notre Dame where Cuomo spoke about abortion and the "proper" role of religion in politics
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The thing about progressivism is that it resembles floor wax -- all shine and no depth
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In his Democratic convention speech, Cuomo referenced Ronald Reagan's line about America being a "shining city on a hill."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Cuomo responded,"A shining city is perhaps all the president sees from the portico of the White House or the veranda of his ranch, where everyone seems to be doing well
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But there's another city; there' s another part to the shining city.... In this part of the city, there are more poor than ever
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: More families in trouble
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: More and more people who need help but can't find it
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: ... There are people who sleep in the city streets, in the gutter where the glitter doesn't show."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This is boilerplate Democratic rhetoric we've heard since the days of Franklin Roosevelt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After Democrats Roosevelt, Truman, Kennedy, Johnson, Carter, Clinton and Obama, are fewer families in trouble?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Are there fewer poor people, especially since Johnson's "War on Poverty" promised to end it?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Statistics reveal there are not
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so why do so many embrace progressive ideas?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: something isn't working
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: why repeat the errors?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As Reagan noted, government too often adds to problems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it doesn' t solve them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Government doesn't create jobs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: a thriving private economy does
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Government welfare mostly doesn't incentivize people to escape poverty, but too often sustains them in poverty and addicts them to government handouts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the issue of church and state, Cuomo bisected the subjects in his Notre Dame speech
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he said he accepted Catholic teaching against capital punishment
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: he rejected its opposition to abortion
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In this, the late Cardinal Joseph Bernardin expressed opposition to both issues while eloquently arguing that the Catholic Church believes that each is part of a "seamless garment" of life and that all life matters and should not be taken by individuals, or the state
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This is another flaw of progressivism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Progressives are happy to embrace church teachings when it favors their political agenda, but reject them when those teachings don't conform to their politics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: My one encounter with Cuomo came after a column I wrote following his 2007 debate with former Speaker Newt Gingrich at Cooper Union in New York, the site of a famous speech by Abraham Lincoln
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I said that Gingrich clearly won the debate and made a mockery of Cuomo's liberalism
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Cuomo called me and after identifying himself launched into a tirade that lasted about 90 seconds
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He then hung up giving me no opportunity to say much more than "hello, nice to hear from you."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Vanity
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Vanity
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Most obituaries and news reports called Cuomo "inspiring."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A New York Times editorial correctly noted:"For all his idealism, Mr  Cuomo's years as governor were dogged by economic recession that blunted his hopes to leave great programs and innovation as his legacy
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He had to cut services and scratch for scarce revenue."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Inspiration is good if it motivates people to do for themselves and improve their lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Otherwise
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's nothing more than floor wax
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: May Gov  Cuomo rest in peace
paragraphs.label: other
